Class Huffman

  • java.lang.Object
    • Compression
      • Huffman

  • public class Huffman
extends Compression
    Huffman is a class that constructs Huffman codes based on any given alphabet or text. Being that the Huffman class is a subclass of Compression it allows the re-use of many essential methods for encoding, decoding, reading, and initializing input.

    Having all codes built a Huffman object retains the ability to calculate the ratio between equal-length encoding and Huffman code encoding. Further, using known entropy equations, a Huffman object allows to calculate the total alphabet entropy and find deviations from any given "optimal" alphabet.

    Let n = size of alphabet
    Let p = probability of a given symbol

    • Entropy for equal-length alphabet = Math.ceil( log(n) / log(2) )
    • Entropy for individual symbol = -p * ( log(p) / log(2) )

    Building codes:

    Step 1: instantiate Huffman class

    Huffman huffmanDictionary = new Huffman();

    Step 2: setup algorithm dictionary from file

    huffmanDictionary.setupDictionaryFromFile("fileName.txt", false);

    Note: in huffmanDictionary.setupDictionaryFromFile(String fileName, boolean isAlphabetRawText) fileName is the name of the file plus a ".txt" extension. Also the boolean isAlphabetRawText should be set true only when the file is actual text. If the file is an alphabet like "a=20, b=13, c=4" then alphabet is not raw text, so isAlphabetRawText should be false.

    Step 3: call setupHuffmanCodes() to build the codes

    huffmanDictionary.setupHuffmanCodes();

    Printing codes:

    huffmanDictionary.printCodes();

        public Huffman()

    • Method Detail

      • setupHuffmanCodes

        public void setupHuffmanCodes()
        Once dictionary from Compression class is initialized from input this method is called to build the Huffman codes. Specifically, an ArrayList<Code> containing all symbols and frequencies is initialized from which a Huffman tree is built. Having this Huffman tree recursion is used to derive the codes for every symbol.

        Precondition: dictionary is initialized from a valid file using setupDictionaryFromFile(String fileName, boolean isAlphabetRawText)

      • buildNodeList

        private java.util.ArrayList<Code> buildNodeList()
        Uses initialized dictionary from Compression class to copy all Code's keys and frequencies and places them in ArrayList<Code>. This ArrayList is later used to build a Huffman tree by combining nodes correspondingly and forming new parent nodes.
        Returns:
        ArrayList<Code> with all dictionary's keys and values

      • buildHuffmanCodes

        private void buildHuffmanCodes(java.util.ArrayList<Code> nodeList)
        Builds Huffman codes by merging nodeList values. This is done by looping through every element in the dictionary while checking keys that match with other keys from nodeList. If a match is found the entry's Huffman code is built recursively by mergeNodeValues(). Checking for a match is necessary as the nodeList contains parent nodes in addition to the original nodes. Because a parent node is a combination of two parentless nodes and does not provide access to it's child nodes values we must filter them out. Passing a parent node to mergeNodeValues() will cut off all child nodes and ultimately produce incorrect codes.
        Parameters:
        nodeList - ArrayList<Code> containing Codes with their symbol, frequency, and parent Code

      • mergeNodeValues

        private java.lang.String mergeNodeValues(Code node)
        This method recursively appends each node's parent code to a String to form a Huffman code.
        Parameters:
        node - a base Code which is not a parent of any other Code
        Returns:
        String with all parent's codes appended to the original code's value that was passed

      • buildHuffmanTree

        private java.util.ArrayList<Code> buildHuffmanTree(java.util.ArrayList<Code> nodeList)
        Builds a Huffman tree from an nodeList. Precisely, the Huffman tree is built through the process of locating two symbols with the smallest frequencies. Once these two symbols are found they are combined into a "parent node." This "parent node" contains the sum of the two symbol's frequencies and their concatenated symbols. Note that when concatenating the symbols the parent node puts the symbol earliest in the given alphabet before the other symbol. Additionally, if their frequencies are not equal, the symbol with the smaller frequency receives a value of "0" and the symbol with the larger frequency receives a value of "1". If the symbols frequencies are equal then the symbol whose first character came earlier in the original alphabet gets the "0" and the symbol whose first character came later in the alphabet gets a "1". This process continues recursively until only one parentless node is left and the Huffman tree is completed.

        Note: a symbol and its frequency is a Code.

        Parameters:
        nodeList - ArrayList<Code> with prebuilt codes from the buildNodeList() method
        Returns:
        an ArrayList<Code> that has all the original Codes from the dictionary plus the new parent codes

      • getMinNode

        private Code getMinNode(java.util.ArrayList<Code> nodeList,
                        Code firstMinNode)
        Finds the smallest Code in nodeList. Note that if firstMinNode == null then it is simply ignored and the smallest Code is returned else firstMinNode is overlooked and the second smallest node is returned
        Parameters:
        nodeList - ArrayList<Code> with prebuilt codes from the buildNodeList() method
        firstMinNode - Code to overlook. This allows to find second smallest Code
        Returns:
        minNode

      • calculateRatio

        public double calculateRatio(int totalTextSize)
                      throws java.lang.Exception
        This method calculates ratio of space needed for encoding a given amount of letters using fixed-length encoding to the space expected to be taken by Huffman code encoding. The ratio for any amount of letters is found by calculating the factor and using it to increase the lengths proportionally.

        Factor: totalTextSize / actual code size

        Parameters:
        totalTextSize - amount of letters to be compared in ratio. If totalTextSize is -1 then calculate ratio as is
        Returns:
        ratio of space needed for encoding a given amount of letters using fixed-length encoding to to the space expected to be taken by Huffman code encoding
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if dictionary is null

      • calculateDeviationFromOptimalEncoding

        private double calculateDeviationFromOptimalEncoding(Huffman comparison)
                                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Finds deviation from the optimal encoding by calculating percent change between the total comparison entropy and the total entropy of the object calling this method.

        Note: the optimal encoding is the total entropy of the object calling this method

        Parameters:
        comparison - object who's entropy is to be compared to
        Returns:
        percent change between this object's and the comparison's total entropy
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if dictionary is null

      • displayDeviationFromOptimalEncoding

        public void displayDeviationFromOptimalEncoding(Huffman comparison,
                                                java.lang.String name)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Prints out the deviation from the optimal encoding in a readable form with an explanation as to what it means.
        Parameters:
        comparison - object who's entropy is to be compared to
        name - name of file from which comparison's alphabet comes from
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if dictionary is null

      • calculateTotalAlphabetEntropy

        public double calculateTotalAlphabetEntropy(boolean printComputations)
                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Finds total alphabet entropy by summing up the entropy of each individual symbol throughout the alphabet.

        Note: entropy for individual symbol in a given alphabet is found by -p * ( log(p) / log(2) ) when p is probability for that symbol

        Parameters:
        printComputations - if true computations are printed else they are not
        Returns:
        the total entropy of this alphabet
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if dictionary is null

      • calculateSumOfFrequencies

        public double calculateSumOfFrequencies(boolean printComputations)
                                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Finds total sum of alphabet's symbol frequencies.
        Parameters:
        printComputations - if true computations are printed else they are not
        Returns:
        sum of alphabet's symbol frequencies
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if dictionary is null

      • findBestBinomials

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> findBestBinomials(java.lang.String alphabetFile,
                                                               java.lang.String binomialFileName,
                                                               boolean findBestBinomial,
                                                               boolean printComputations)
                                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Finds the best binomial(s) by testing how each would affect the total alphabet entropy.
        Parameters:
        alphabetFile - name of while in which alphabet is located
        binomialFileName - name of while in which binomial is located
        findBestBinomial - if true finds single best binomial else finds all best binomials that together reduce the total entropy
        printComputations - if true computations are printed else they are not
        Returns:
        best binomial(s) found that help reduce entropy of alphabet
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if dictionary is null

        Precondition: alphabetFile and binomialFileName have ".txt" extension. Example: if file name is "alphabet" pass as "alphabet.txt"
